item.title: Afghanistan: Tony Blair says sacrifices were not in vain
item.description: The ex-PM criticises the US decision to withdraw its military as "tragic, dangerous, and unnecessary".

item.title: Afghanistan: British evacuation improving, says armed forces minister
item.description: More than 1,700 people have been airlifted out of Afghanistan in the past 24 hours, says James Heappey.

item.title: Covid: Antibody tests offered to public for first time
item.description: The UK-wide scheme for adults who test positive for coronavirus will launch next week.

item.title: Everly Brothers: US rock 'n' roll star Don Everly dies aged 84
item.description: The rock 'n' roll duo were known for their harmonies and influenced bands including The Beatles.

item.title: Kenya holds biggest ever animal census
item.description: All wildlife on land and sea is being counted to help Kenya's conservation plans and tourism.

item.title: Hurricane Grace kills eight as it rips through eastern Mexico
item.description: The powerful storm brings torrential rain and high winds, causing power cuts and flooding.

item.title: Storm Henri: US East Coast warned of significant damage
item.description: New York state declares a state of emergency as officials warn of flooding and power outages.

item.title: Covid: New Zealand pandemic strategy in doubt amid Delta spread
item.description: The highly infectious Delta variant "does change the game", the Covid response minister says.

item.title: The best action from the Hundred finals
item.description: Watch the best of the action from the Hundred finals at Lord's as Southern Brave took on Birmingham Phoenix in the men's final and Oval Invincibles in the women's final.

item.title: Eileen Barrott death: Husband charged with murder
item.description: Eileen Barrott died at the couple's home a week ago after being found seriously injured.

item.title: Man arrested over Birmingham Gay Village attack
item.description: Two men needed hospital treatment after the attack which began with abuse from inside a car.

item.title: Five hurt in high-speed crash at Lincoln car meet
item.description: Police say the five people were seriously injured when two cars went into spectators.

item.title: The NI inventor who saved thousands of lives
item.description: The plane ejector seat was invented by James Martin, from Crossgar in County Down, in 1944.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Blair's attack on US exit, and UN aid warning
item.description: Former UK prime minister Tony Blair's comments on Afghanistan make many of Sunday's front pages.

item.title: Green Man: Festival returns in the Welsh mountains after Covid restrictions
item.description: Wales' largest music festival, Green Man, returns with 25,000 people in attendance.

item.title: 'Race should not be a factor in my destiny'
item.description: A young Londoner beats 23,000 other entrants in one of the country's largest anti-racism competitions.

item.title: Nigeria's royal wedding: Private jets, glitz and glamour
item.description: President Buhari's son marries the daughter of a religious leader in one of Nigeria's events of the year.

item.title: Banksy: Rusty old boat a 'godsend' destined for museum
item.description: The small metal "boat" under a painting of three children could become a museum piece.

item.title: Dorothy Butler Gilliam: 'I am not a maid, I am a reporter'
item.description: The first black female reporter on the Washington Post says some colleagues would pretend not to know her.

item.title: Algeria's desperate wildfire fight: Buckets and branches
item.description: Despite a huge military budget, oil-rich Algeria is ill-equipped to tackle annual fires.

item.title: Love Island: Is the dating show's honeymoon phase over?
item.description: The ITV show sparked record complaints, so as the latest series ends, is the magic starting to fade?

item.title: Tabletop gaming: The therapy of fighting with miniature dragons
item.description: The popularity of gaming during the pandemic helped with mental health and family life, say fans.

item.title: Sent to Halifax: One town's asylum story
item.description: What life is like for asylum seekers in a Yorkshire town - and what locals think about accepting more.

item.title: OnlyFans: How it handles illegal sex videos - BBC investigation
item.description: Announcement came as leaked documents revealed Only Fans had some “tolerance” for accounts that posted illegal content.

item.title: Biden's week of blame and tumult after Kabul fall
item.description: How the fall of Kabul stunned the Biden administration and spawned the worst week of his presidency.

item.title: Wolverhampton Wanderers v Tottenham Hotspur: Harry Kane named on visitors' bench
item.description: Tottenham striker Harry Kane is on the bench for Sunday's Premier League match at Wolves as he continues to be linked with Manchester City.

item.title: The Hundred: Has the new tournament been a success?
item.description: After a month of cricket, the inaugural season of The Hundred is over. BBC Sport looks at whether the new tournament has been a success.

item.title: 10.54 - Thompson-Herah runs second-fastest women's 100m of all time
item.description: Olympic champion Elaine Thompson-Herah runs the second fastest time in women's 100m history as she clocks 10.54 seconds in Eugene.

item.title: Match of the Day analysis: How Danny Ings scored his 'fabulous' bicycle kick for Aston Villa
item.description: Match of the Day's Gary Lineker, Jermaine Jenas and Danny Murphy analyse Danny Ings' "fabulous" bicycle kick for Aston Villa in their 2-0 win over Newcastle United.

item.title: Afghanistan: Where will refugees go after Taliban takeover?
item.description: Thousands of people are scrambling to flee Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: The desperate scramble to escape
item.description: The BBC witnesses scenes of chaos and panic as thousands still crowd Kabul's airport.

item.title: Afghanistan: Trapped Nottingham family reach Dubai
item.description: The family with two young children were helped to escape from Kabul by the children's head teacher.

item.title: Afghan crisis: Russia plans for new era with Taliban rule
item.description: While Western governments raced to get their people out, Russia appears unfazed by the takeover.

item.title: Family of American taken by Taliban beg for return
item.description: Mark Frerichs, 59, one of the last Americans kidnapped by the Taliban, is stuck in Afghanistan.

item.title: How Afghanistan's media is changing under Taliban rule
item.description: The Taliban are currently on a media offensive but does their rhetoric match what’s happening on the ground?

item.title: 'They will kill me': Desperate Afghans seek way out after Taliban takeover
item.description: Many Afghans are desperate to escape after the Taliban takeover. Some fear there is no way out.

item.title: Afghanistan: Tears and applause as UK appeal helps refugees
item.description: People in Chapel-en-le-Frith in the Peak District collected more than 1,000 bags of donations in 48 hours.

item.title: The treacherous road to Kabul's airport
item.description: As thousands try to flee Afghanistan, the main route to the capital's airport has become treacherous.

item.title: Facebook moves to protect Afghan users' accounts amid Taliban takeover
item.description: The tech giant says it wants to reassure people worried about being tracked down by the Taliban.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as more than 47 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: Covid: Do I have to self-isolate if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: Self-isolation rules have now been relaxed across the UK.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for £10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.
